AUCTION SALE!
To be sold by public auction at the Police Barracks, Prince Albert, on the
1st of March, 1885, at 12 o'clock.

ONE FUN-COLOURED BEEF.
The property of the North-West Mounted Police.

By order,

GEO. H. MONTAGUE,
Inspector.

TENDERS
Will be received by the Officer commanding North-West Mounted Police, Prince Albert, up to 12 o'clock, next Monday.

For the Second Day of March next.

For the delivery of

150 Cords of Cordwood.

At North-West Mounted Police Barracks, Prince Albert.

Delivered to be commenced not later than September next, and in quantities as ordered.

To be loaded flat, cut in four lengths, and split average cordwood size.

To be of this winter's or spring's cutting.

No tenders will be received for the whole quantity or for his lots less than eighty-five cords.

Tenders to include Government tax in their dues.

The person to whom contract is awarded will be required to furnish satisfactory security, which may be cash bonds or sureties as may be desired.

The lowest or any tender not exceeding the above.

LORD'S DAY.
As we intend dissolving part-
ments on Lord's Day, we request to
us must settle our accounts in full by 6 o'clock on or before the last day of April, 1885, otherwise our accounts will be placed in court for collection.

MARKLEY & CO.

vision of Lot 78, the property of the late John Flatt.

McLEAN & ELLIOT, Venturers Solicitors.

G. & E. CARTER.

Orders left at J. L. Johnson & Co.'s will be promptly attended to.

NATHANIEL ACORN,
Prince Albert.

THE SCHOOL BOARD.

The adjourned meeting of the School Board was held in the school house on Friday afternoon, when the trustees were all present.

After the meeting was formally opened, it was moved by Mr. Macintosh, secon-
ded by Mr. Stewart, that Mr. Macintosh, Mr. Stewart, and Macdonald be appointed to the Rev. Mr. Parker in reference to the question of the proposed Church by a sub-committee. Carried.

It was then resolved that Mr. Murray, who sat on Miss Baker's committee for arranging the schoolhouse for the school, be re-
warded for his services.

The applications for vacancy and se-
niority were read, and Mr. Murray, Mr. Macintosh, Mr. Stewart, and W. R. Marshall, former trustees, were elected to the vacancy, and Mr. Macintosh was declared elected.

The board then adjourned until the first Tuesday in March at ten o'clock.

The trustees report to be convened in the new building in the spring.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1885

We are glad to see that steps are being taken by the passage of an Act at the opening session of the Manitoba Legislature to put an end to the wrongdoings from dishonest contractors who have been working in the very difficult coal fields and who have been engaged in the mining operations. The provisions of the new law will be enforced immediately and all those who have been engaged in these illegal operations will be prosecuted to the full extent of the law.

The Canadian Tribune says: "The situation in the coal fields of Manitoba is now becoming so serious that it will be necessary to take immediate steps to prevent further loss of life and property. The government has already appointed a commission to investigate the conditions and to report its findings to Parliament."

SLANG.

Slang has this value that it makes language grow. The English tongue is so vigorous that it seems whatever it needs for growth, just as it did in its infancy. At this juncture, there are times when words are made into words by the young rascalhood to-day use "think" for "money." Further on in the tongue, it took a very ordinary speech to make of them till they had the use of some of their limbs for a long time, and in several cases it was found necessary to resort to suppositions.

Buffalo Hall!

Still continues to be a source of annoyance to general business men.

Fresh goods this week.

Teas, Tobaccos, Sugars, Oatmeal, Canned Goods.

The prices for the past three months have given the greatest satisfaction. It is now our intention to cease the sale of our stock remaining at still greater reductions.

The public will do a fine thing if they examine fully our lines in Dry Goods, Clothing, Muffs, Mocamboes, Fans, Groceries and Provisions before purchasing.

The largest stock of Fine Muffs and Mocamboes.

The largest stock of Groceries and Provisions.

And the largest reductions from old-time prices will be found at Buffalo Hall.

BETTS & GWYNNE.

TELEGRAHIC.
The Latest News from the East

OTTAWA, Feb. 18.—A mob of 500 men attacked the Hon. Mr. Gladstone's House in London and ordered the Admiralty officers to leave. They were driven back by the police.

Queen Victoria is ill, caused by cold weather, and worrying over Government affairs.

Sir Graham and staff set sail immediately for the Suez Canal.

The Gordon was also attacked, but not severely. The Austrian Consul was shot at the same time.

A contract has been given for the construction of a railway from Suez to Baghdad.

Several victories have been gained by the French in China.

A large delegation of natives appeared before the Government, urging an increase of duty on imported goods from the United States.

Gordon's Helicon Bay report shows that the Straits are navigable for four months in the year.

There has been severe snowstorms in Quebec. Traffic has been almost suspended.

Coxcough and Barton have been identified as dynamiters and remnants of a week.

Several Canadian regiments have volunteered their services for Egypt. General Wolseley expresses his desire of accepting them.

NEW YORK, Feb. 9.—Richard Short, who had been arrested in the office of Dominion Secretary, was released on $3,000 bail today after efforts had been made to secure his release for $250.

LONDON, Feb. 9.—Yesterday the Government received word that the new law courts would be thrown open with all the courts in the building at two in the afternoon, to clear the building and turn it into a hospital for wounded patients.

Special precautions in addition to those already taken by the police have been arranged for the safety of the Chief and Canterbury cathedrals against dynamite.

GENERAL NEWS.

LOCHINVAR, Feb. 5.—The completion of the Canadian Pacific Railway will provide England with a new route to Hong Kong, occupying but little over a month, or sixteen days less than the Suez Canal route. The possibility of using Egyptian land to land troops in China, two days earlier than French transports, is being considered.
